Chorus 1 – 0:25 – 0:35

Chorus 2 – 0:49 – 0:58

The chorus is a simple tune sung twice, four times in the last cycle. The vocals are in unison and the octave harmonies are overdubbed many times for creating a mass-chant effect. The pitch set of the lead vocal is added in the 2nd degree.
[Verse 1]

Verse 1 – 0:13 – 0:24



The eight-measure verse doesn’t have much to analyze. The start of the second lyrical phrase (“playing…”) falls on the third beat of the second measure and the pitch-set is pentatonic. The closing of the section descends an octave below the starting notes.
[Guitar Solo]

1:33 – 2:02



A long, fading-in, feedback E note introduces Brian May’s famous guitar solo outro, which is the only time a melodic instrument is played in the song.  In most performances, this song transitioned into “We are the Champions.”



The solo itself is built around the A and D/A chords, with lots of double and triple-stops. There’s pedal bass on the open A string, with hardly any single-note passages during the solo. The solo ends with a thrice-played phrase reminiscent of the triple-tag ending heard on “Seaside Rendezvous”. On the album cut of the song, this phrase was repeated by means of a tape loop, rather than being played by May that way, according to an interview May gave to NPR’s Terry Gross:

…You may notice that the last piece, the very last little riffs, are repeated, and they’re not just repeated by me playing them again. They’re repeated by cutting the tape and splicing it on again and again…"

We will, we will rock you
 We will, we will rock you

One interpretation of the song is that it’s about how society looks down on people and tries to control them throughout their lives. The verses show how society berates the main character and calls him a disgrace, first as a boy, then as a young man, and finally as an old man. “We will rock you” could be interpreted as saying society will dominate you, try to keep you from achieving your dreams, etc.

It’s interesting that this song and We Are the Champions were released as opposite sides of the same single. We Are the Champions could also be seen as the “opposite side of the coin” metaphorically; in contrast, it’s an empowering song about affirming yourself and achieving your dreams despite the obstacles.

Waving your banner
 All over the place
This, along with “shouting in the street”, seems like he has strong (probably anti-establishment) political views, and goes to a lot of protests and rallies.

You got mud on your face
 Big disgrace

The phrase “blood on your face” in the second verse reverts back to “mud on your face”.

So Buddy has now come full circle to when he was a boy.

Buddy, you’re a young man, hard man
 Shouting in the street
 Gonna take on the world someday

This line is part of the transition through life of the boy, and right now he is in his rebellious teens/young adult.

The boy has grown into a “hard man” and now instead of just playing in the street by kicking the can, he now shouts in order to attract attention.
If he keeps going down this path, he will be beaten by someone at the end.

Kicking your can
 All over the place, singing

Making noise around the neighborhood by kicking a can which annoys everyone. Also, we must remember that at this age he is a little kid, and kicking a can is quite a good way to pass the time when you are bored



It is interesting to note that “kicking the can down the road” is an expression meaning you are delay a decision in hopes that the problem or issue will go away. The character in this song is definitely in for some trouble later on in life, so this could be foreshadowing to that.

Buddy, you’re an old man, poor man
 Pleading with your eyes
 Gonna make you some peace someday

The boy Queen was referring to in the beginning has now grown old, and has done nothing with life, he has wasted his time and now he has no money left to spend.
The grown up man now pleads with his eyes, which means that the only way he can make some money is by begging in the streets, but since he is old, he will not last much longer out there.

Somebody better put you back
 Into your place

Buddy, now a grown man, needs to be told by somebody that begging for money in the streets won’t get him anywhere. Even though he doesn’t have the life of a youthful boy, he still has time to accomplish some of his big dreams and ambitions. However, If he keeps idly waiting for things to change, they won’t.
